description: The NOAA Global Surface Temperature Dataset (NOAAGlobalTemp) is a merged land-ocean surface temperature analysis (formerly known as MLOST). It is a spatially gridded (5° - 5°) global surface temperature dataset, with monthly resolution from January 1850 to present. We combine a global sea surface (water) temperature (SST) dataset with a global land surface air temperature datasets. The SST dataset is the Extended Reconstructed Sea Surface Temperature (ERSST) version 5. The land surface air temperature dataset is similar to ERSST but uses data from the Global Historical Climatology Network Monthly (GHCNm) database, version 4. Also used are ICOADS and IABD data. We provide the NOAAGlobalTemp dataset as temperature anomalies, relative to a 1971-2000 monthly climatology, following the World Meteorological Organization convention. This is the dataset NOAA uses for global temperature monitoring.

The Extended Reconstructed Sea Surface Temperature (ERSST) dataset is a global monthly sea surface temperature dataset derived from the International Comprehensive Ocean-Atmosphere Dataset (ICOADS). Production of the ERSST is on a 2° - 2° grid with spatial completeness enhanced using statistical methods. This monthly analysis begins in January 1854 continuing to the present and includes anomalies computed with respect to a 1971-2000 monthly climatology. The newest version of ERSST, version 5, uses new data sets from ICOADS Release 3.0 (Sea Surface Temperatures) SST; SST comes from Argo floats above 5 meters, Hadley Centre Ice-SST version 2 (HadISST2) ice concentration. ERSSTv5 has improved SST spatial and temporal variability by (a) reducing spatial filtering in training the reconstruction functions Empirical Orthogonal Teleconnections (EOTs), (b) removing high-latitude damping in EOTs, and (c) adding 10 more EOTs in the Arctic. ERSSTv5 improved absolute SST by switching from using Nighttime Marine Air Temperature (NMAT) as a reference to buoy-SST as a reference in correcting ship SST biases. Scientists have further improved ERSSTv5 by using unadjusted First-Guess instead of adjusted First-Guess.

The GPCP Monthly product provides a consistent analysis of global precipitation from an integration of various satellite data sets over land and ocean and a gauge analysis over land. Data from rain gauge stations, satellites, and sounding observations have been merged to estimate monthly rainfall on a 2.5-degree global grid from 1979 to the present. The careful combination of satellite-based rainfall estimates provides the most complete analysis of rainfall available to date over the global oceans, and adds necessary spatial detail to the rainfall analyses over land. In addition to the combination of these data sets, estimates of the uncertainties in the rainfall analysis are provided as a part of the GPCP products.

The NOAA Twentieth Century Reanalysis Version 3 (20CRv3) is a global atmospheric reanalysis dataset that reconstructs historical weather and climate conditions using surface pressure observations combined with a modern numerical weather prediction model. Surface pressure data are drawn from the International Surface Pressure Databank (ISPD v4.7) through international collaboration coordinated by the ACRE initiative and global climate research programs. 20CRv3 assimilates surface pressure observations using an ensemble Kalman filter with a four-dimensional incremental analysis update and is driven by prescribed sea surface temperature and sea ice boundary conditions derived primarily from HadISST datasets. The system employs the NCEP Global Forecast System (GFS v14.0.1) coupled with land surface and thermodynamic sea ice models, operating at approximately 75 km horizontal resolution with 64 vertical levels and 80 ensemble members. Spanning the mid-19th century to the present, 20CRv3 provides a physically consistent framework for studying long-term climate variability, extreme events, and atmospheric circulation changes across the historical record.

datasetName: NCEP Global Ocean Data Assimilation System
description: GODAS is a real-time ocean analysis and a reanalysis. It is used for monitoring, retrospective analysis as well as for providing oceanic initial conditions for the CFS. Both temperature and synthetic salinity profiles are assimilated in a 3DVAR scheme designed by Derber and Rosati (1989). 40 vertical levels are in the model together with 1x1 data values (enhanced in resolution to 1/3x1/3 degrees latitude within 10 degrees of the equator). The data is provided at 1/3x1/3 degrees for all latitudes. The GODAS is forced by the momentum flux, heat flux and fresh water flux from the NCEP atmospheric Reanalysis 2. It appears to reproduce observations quite well (see the references).

The NOAA Mean Layer Temperature Climate Data Record (CDR), developed by the National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI), provides a globally consistent, long-term dataset of atmospheric temperature trends. The dataset offers global coverage on a 2.5° × 2.5° equal-angle grid and is produced at a monthly temporal resolution. It includes measurements across multiple atmospheric layers—lower stratosphere (TLS), upper troposphere (TUT), mid-troposphere (TMT), and lower troposphere (TLT)—with records spanning from 1978 to the present and updated monthly. This CDR is widely used for detecting long-term climate change and variability in atmospheric temperatures, validating climate model simulations, identifying climate extremes, and cross-validating other observational datasets. Its standardized methodology and long temporal coverage make it a critical resource for climate monitoring, research, and assessment activities.

The NOAA CMORPH (Climate Prediction Center Morphing Technique) Precipitation Climate Data Record (CDR), produced by the National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI), provides a high-resolution, global dataset of surface precipitation rates. The record offers near-global coverage at an 8 km × 8 km (0.25° latitude/longitude) spatial resolution, with observations spanning from 1998 to the present and updated on a monthly basis. This Climate Data Record is designed to support the analysis of long-term precipitation patterns and variability. It is commonly used to characterize global precipitation evolution, validate climate model simulations, identify precipitation-related climate extremes, and cross-validate other observational datasets. Additionally, the CMORPH CDR serves as a critical forcing input for numerical weather prediction, climate modeling, and hydrological modeling applications, making it an essential resource for climate research and operational analysis.

datasetName: Sea Surface Temperature – Optimum Interpolation CDR
description: The NOAA Optimum Interpolation Sea Surface Temperature (OISST) Climate Data Record (CDR), maintained by the National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI), provides a high-resolution, globally consistent dataset of ocean surface conditions. The product delivers daily global coverage at a 0.25° × 0.25° spatial resolution, with records extending from 1981 to the present. Preliminary data are updated daily, while finalized datasets are released every 15 days to ensure both timeliness and accuracy. This Climate Data Record includes key oceanic variables such as sea surface temperature, sea surface height, and sea ice concentration. OISST is widely used for predicting El Niño and La Niña events, forecasting typhoon intensity and monsoon rainfall, estimating fishery yields, and studying coral reef bleaching. Its long temporal coverage and consistent methodology make it a foundational dataset for oceanographic research, climate monitoring, and operational forecasting applications.

The NOAA Global Ocean Heat Content Climate Data Record (CDR), produced by the National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI), provides a globally consistent dataset of ocean temperature anomalies at multiple depth levels. The dataset offers global coverage on a 1° × 1° grid with monthly temporal resolution, spanning from January 2005 to December 2020. It includes objectively analyzed temperature anomaly fields (t_an) across 26 standard depth levels from the surface to 2000 meters. This CDR is derived from the World Ocean Atlas and is widely used for monitoring ocean heat uptake and redistribution, understanding climate variability and long-term trends, validating ocean components of climate models, and studying the role of the ocean in the global energy budget. The multi-level structure enables analysis of heat content changes at different ocean depths, providing critical insights into ocean warming patterns and their implications for sea level rise and climate change.

The NOAA Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) Climate Data Record (CDR), produced by the National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI), provides a globally consistent, high-resolution dataset for monitoring vegetation health and dynamics. The product offers global coverage at a 0.05° × 0.05° spatial resolution and is available as a daily product, with records extending from 1981 to the present and updated daily. This Climate Data Record includes the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI), a widely used indicator of vegetation greenness and condition. The NDVI CDR supports a range of applications including the detection of drought-stressed regions, agricultural yield forecasting, analysis of long-term phenological patterns, and forestry and crop management. Its long temporal span and frequent updates make it a critical resource for ecosystem monitoring, land-surface analysis, and climate impact assessments.
